Project Description  The  Project  is  in  Sichuan  Province  in  the  poor  southwestern 
region  of  the  PRC.  In  2004,  the  per  capita  gross  domestic 
product of Sichuan was only 72% of the national average. The 
Project will support the Government’s strategy by building an 
important section of the western region corridor connecting two 
growth centers—Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan, and Kunming, 
the  capital  of  Yunnan  Province—by  (i) constructing  an 
expressway  across  mountainous  terrain;  (ii) improving  local 
roads servicing poor counties and townships; and (iii) providing 
consulting services and training to enhance capacity at the local 
communications bureau, construction quality, road safety, and 
project monitoring and evaluation. 
   
Rationale  Despite  considerable investment  in  the  road  sector,  the PRC 
road network is still inadequate and does not provide efficient 
access to large parts of the country, particularly in the poorer 
inland  regions,  including  Sichuan.  Better  transport  links  are 
necessary to improve economic efficiency, foster domestic and 
international trade, facilitate interregional economic integration, 
and  promote  efficient  economic  growth,  thereby  reducing 
poverty.  Western  PRC  lacks  high-class  and  local  road 
infrastructure.  The  integrated  road  network  comprising 
expressways and local roads must therefore be developed to 
spread  economic  and  social  benefits.  To  enhance  economic 
development  and  reduce  poverty  in  the  western  region,  the 
Government is implementing the Western Region Development 
Strategy. The strategy aims to reduce development disparities 
between  the  western  and  coastal  regions.  The  Project  will 
support this strategy by developing an integrated road network 
comprising expressways and local roads. The Sichuan provincial 
government  (SPG)  has  identified  the  Project  as  a  priority 
investment,  which  will  link  up  with  an  ongoing  ADB-financed 
Southern  Sichuan  Roads  Development  Project,  thereby 
facilitating completion of the 900-kilometer (km) route connecting 
Chengdu and Kunming.

road  transport  system  to  support  sustainable  economic 
development  in  Sichuan.  Local  roads  will  complement  the 
expressway in bringing benefits to rural residents. The Project 
will (i) reduce traffic accidents and vehicle operating costs; (ii) 
improve  access  between  Chengdu  and  Kunming;  (iii)  provide 
additional transport capacity to accommodate growing traffic; (iv) 
improve access to jobs, markets, and social services; and (v) 
develop  the  capacity  of  local  communications  bureaus.  The 
Project has the following components: (i) construction of a 244 
km, four-lane access-controlled toll expressway from Ya’an to 
Lugu,  including  access  roads,  interchanges  with  toll  stations, 
tunnels, bridges, administrative stations, and service areas; (ii) 
upgrading of 678 km of local roads to improve access to poor 
remote  areas,  and  roadside  stations;  (iii)  construction  of  four 
public transport centers; (iv) procurement of equipment for road 
maintenance,  toll  collection,  surveillance  and  communications, 
tunnel  operation  facilities,  vehicle weigh  stations,  road  safety, 
and office administration; (v) land acquisition and resettlement; 
(vi) consulting services for construction supervision, road safety 
audit, monitoring and evaluation, and capacity building; and (v) 
developing  local  communications  bureaus’  capacity  for 
maintenance.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Central Sichuan Roads Development Project. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  The PRC’s economic growth since the 1980s has substantially increased the demand for 
transport services. The economy’s changing structure and increasing diversification have altered 
the pattern of transport demand. The demand for road transport has outpaced that of other 
transport modes. There is a rapidly increasing movement of goods and passengers by road, 
which is more flexible and responsive than other modes to the needs of a market economy. The 
shift in transport demand also reflects the loosening of anticompetitive restrictions in the road 
transport industry itself. From 1990 to 2004, road traffic grew by 9.0% per annum (p.a.) for 
passenger traffic, reaching 876.5 billion passenger-kilometers (km); and by 6.0% p.a. for freight, 
reaching 759.7 billion ton-km. In Sichuan, road traffic grew by 6.5% p.a. for passenger traffic, 
reaching 51.7 billion passenger-km, and by 4.2% p.a. for freight, reaching 27.2 billion ton-km. In 
2004, road traffic accounted for 53.7% of the country’s total passenger traffic and 11.4% of the 
total freight traffic while the corresponding figures for Sichuan Province were 76.0% and 26.3%. 
The vehicle fleet will continue to expand with the country’s rapid economic growth, low vehicle 
ownership rates, lower automobile prices after World Trade Organization accession, increasing 
access  to  loans  to  finance  automobile  purchases,  and  large  investment  in  automotive 
manufacturing. 
 
3.  To meet the growing demand for improved transport infrastructure and services, the 
Government’s policy for the road sector, as reflected in its 10th Five-Year Plan (2001–2005), calls 
for (i) accelerating the construction of the network of highways and national roads, with a focus on 
five north–south and seven east–west sections of the national trunk highway system; (ii) starting 
construction of eight new highways for 18,000 km in the western region; (iii) by 2005, opening 
approximately 1.95 million km of highways to traffic, with expressways1 accounting for 35,000 km; 
and (iv) starting the national expressway network plan to complete 85,000 km by 2040 with 
annual investment of CNY100 billion–150 billion. 
 
4.  While the national trunk highway system is being developed, accessibility in most of rural 
PRC is still low: 145 townships and 50,124 villages, most in the western region, have no access 
to all-weather roads. Many townships and villages still depend on earth tracks that are not 
suitable for motorized traffic and become impassable during the rainy season. Even where all-
weather roads have been built, the standard of rural roads is low, maintenance is poor, and many 
roads need rehabilitation. The central Government thus completed 71,000 km of rural roads at 
the cost of CNY60.9 billion, supported by the local governments that constructed 68,000 km, 
costing CNY57.6 billion, in 2004. The Government targets developing a road network that will 
reach 99.8% of townships by 2005. The Government plans to invest CNY100 billion in developing 
rural roads during the 11th Five-Year Plan (2006–2010). By 2010, all villages in the eastern 
region will be linked with paved roads, and the same targets will be applied to 80% villages in the 
central  region  and  90%  towns  in  the  western  region.  In  2003,  the  Sichuan  Provincial 
Communications Department (SPCD) prepared the Sichuan Province Rural Road Development

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
6.  Sichuan  is  in  southwestern  PRC,  surrounded  by  mountains.  Its  isolation  has  been 
reduced by improved navigation on the Yangtze River, railway construction, and the construction 
of several major highways. Most of the population is concentrated on the flat, fertile plain in the 
east and central east, but the province contains several poverty-stricken areas in its mountainous 
periphery, where the Project is located. Despite rapid development in recent years, Sichuan ranks 
seventh lowest of all provinces in terms of gross domestic product (GDP) per capita: CNY7,514 in 
2004, or 72% of the national average. The per capita rural income was CNY2,580, or 88% of the 
national average. About one third of the counties are officially designated as poor. There are 
282,500 poor people in the project area, equivalent to 29% of the total population, living below the 
income levels of CNY900 per year in rural areas and the minimum living standards in urban areas. 
 
7.  Based on the findings of the feasibility study under an ADB-financed technical assistance 
(TA),3 one  reason  for  high  poverty  is  slow  economic  growth,  partly  because  of  inadequate 
infrastructure. Despite the considerable investments, the road network in the project area is still 
inadequate and does not provide efficient transport access to markets and social services such 
as education and health. Around 30% of villages in Hanyuan and Mianning still have no road 
access. Over the whole project area, over 60% of villages have paved road access but only one 
third have bus services. The proportions in Shimian and Mianning are much lower, with under a 
quarter of villages having paved road access and less than 20% having bus services. In the last 3 
years, local governments have improved access to 13 townships (10% of the total) and 29 
villages (4%). These road improvements have led to the provision of bus services to these

8.  The impact of road investments on poverty reduction is supported by the results of studies 
and evaluations of several completed road projects financed by ADB4 and the World Bank.5 Well-
integrated road development helps ensure that the benefits derived from the expressway filter 
down to the poor. Benefits from transport cost savings and time savings, along with an increase 
in incomes, will be passed on through the transport chain to townships and villages. These results 
affirm the relevance of ADB’s strategy in the PRC road sector. A TA6 will help the Government 
formulate a road network strategy that better integrates expressways and local roads to meet 
communities’ needs and support economic growth, and that provides road agencies with cross-
disciplinary skills and tools through capacity building. A case study in Shaanxi Province found that 
improved roads were correlated with poverty reduction, and that (i) 3.2 poor people are lifted out 
of poverty for every CNY10,000 invested in roads; and (ii) for every 1% increase in kilometer of 
road per capita, household consumption increases by 0.08%.7 Benefits for rural poor areas 
include  lower  transport  costs;  lower  cost  of  inputs;  expanded  agricultural  support  services; 
improved farming practices; greater access to urban jobs; and better access to health, education, 
and social services.8 
 
9.  To help the Government develop its road sector strategy and investment projects, external

C.  Policy Dialogue 
 
10.  Integrated Design and ADB Financing of the Local Road Component. The rural poor 
have limited mobility beyond their immediate communities because of their geographical isolation 
and the high cost of motorized transport. As a result, they generally view local roads as a key 
infrastructure investment priority. Benefits for poor rural areas include lower transport costs, lower 
cost of inputs, expanded agricultural support services, and therefore improved farming practices, 
greater access to urban jobs and to health, education, and social services. Better roads promote 
the transition from a subsistence farming rural economy to a cash crop and more diversified 
economy with a higher and more stable income flow to rural households, reducing poverty. Better 
integration of the local roads into the trunk highway system will help bring benefits to the poor 
more effectively. 
 
11.  The  dialogue  with  the  Government  focused  on  the  need  to  integrate  the  local  road 
component into the project scope with ADB’s financing to establish a credible linkage between 
poverty reduction and ADB’s assistance based on the experience of the ongoing and completed 
ADB-financed road projects since 1995.10 The Government agreed to integrate the local road 
component with ADB’s financing; the component comprised 678 km (Appendix 5), which was 
selected on the basis of population density, poverty incidence, and road network efficiency from 
the Sichuan Provincial Rural Road Development Plan. These roads are in poor condition and are 
not passable during the rainy season. Upon completion, they will connect the main trunk highway 
and the poor or minority townships and villages in the Project’s hinterland. The Project will 
upgrade the roads to higher road class, costing $68.8 million, of which $17.5 million will be 
financed from the ADB loan. The local road component, together with the expressway, will serve 
938,930 people in the project area, of whom about 273,000, or 29%, are poor, living on under

connect major growth centers and link the hinterland economies; (ii) integration of the network so 
that the national trunk highway system is supported by a system of local roads, particularly those 
that  provide  access  to  poor  areas;  (iii) promotion  of  road  safety  and  reduction  of  vehicle

(vi) adoption of pricing policies to ensure optimum use of road transport capacity; and (vii) use of 
alternative methods of investment financing, including private sector participation. ADB road 
sector assistance targets the less developed central and western provinces, where most of the

strategy.

poverty. Western PRC lacks high-class road infrastructure in and outside the region, and between 
and within provinces in the region. The road network must be developed to facilitate sustainable 
economic development and ensure that investments impact poor areas and rural residents in the

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
21.  The  Project  will  develop  an  integrated  road  transport  system  to  support  sustainable 
economic development in Sichuan. Local roads will complement the expressway in bringing 
benefits to rural residents. The Project will (i) reduce traffic accidents and vehicle operating costs; 
(ii) improve access between Chengdu and Kunming, two major growth centers in southwestern 
PRC;  (iii)  provide  additional  transport  capacity  to  accommodate  growing  traffic;  (iv)  improve 
access  to  jobs,  markets,  and  social  services;  and  (v)  develop  the  capacity  of  local 
communications bureaus. 
 
B.  Outputs 
 
22.  The Project integrates the expressway and local roads in its design to benefit townships 
and villages. The Project has the following components: (i) construction of a 244 km, four-lane 
access-controlled toll expressway from Ya’an to Lugu, including access roads, interchanges with 
toll stations, tunnels, bridges, administrative stations, and service areas; (ii) upgrading of 678 km 
of local roads to improve access to poor remote areas, and roadside stations; (iii) rehabilitation of 
four public transport centers; (iv) procurement of equipment for road maintenance, toll collection, 
surveillance and communications, tunnel operation facilities, vehicle weigh stations, road safety, 
and  office  administration;  (v)  land  acquisition  and  resettlement;  (vi)  consulting  services  for 
construction supervision, road safety audit, monitoring and evaluation, and capacity building; and 
(v) developing capacity of local communications bureaus for maintenance. 
 
C.  Special Features 
 
23.  Public Transport Center. Because of the poor road infrastructure in the project area, 
public transport service is inadequate, given the limited routes and bus service in remote poor 
areas. Many towns and villages with poor or no road access still have no direct bus service. For 
example, only 63% of towns are served by bus in Mianning county. Bus service in villages is even 
more limited, from 17% in Mianning to 50% in Hanyuan county. No cross-county routes provide 
direct connections across township boundaries without going through township centers. In order 
to provide poor, remote areas with better public transport services, Sichuan plans to develop 9 
provincial public transport centers by 2015, with 90 county public transport centers, including

9 
rehabilitation of 4 that are included in the Project. Each center will have a handling capacity of 
5,000 passengers per day, enable longer public transport routes that can reach towns and 
villages, improve the quality of service, reduce costs to users, and ensure more efficient use of 
bus fleet. An assessment of transport services is in Appendix 6. 
 
24.  Intelligent Transport System. An intelligent transport system (ITS)30 on expressways is 
being introduced in accordance with the national ITS architecture prepared by the National ITS 
Center. In Sichuan, an expressway ITS policy is being drafted to (i) introduce a network-wide 
expressway tolling system; (ii) reduce toll payment delay; (iii) improve safety through enhanced 
monitoring; (iv) improve traveler information; (iv) assist in emergencies; and (v) improve traffic 
enforcement, infrastructure maintenance, and computerized management of urgent incidents. 
The use of an ITS will be built into the Project through procurement of equipment and training and 
will be implemented with the help of the international consultants. ITS includes (i) fewer traffic 
control centers; (ii) advanced toll payment; (iii) variable message displays to improve driver 
information; (iv) use of surveillance technology; and (v) detection of blackspot locations and 
weather conditions; (vi) monitoring of speed limit, overloaded vehicles, and toll payment; and (v) 
provision of current information to improve road safety (Supplementary Appendix D). 
 
25.  Asset Management. Expressway companies in Sichuan do not make significant use of 
modern techniques in their asset management and road maintenance programs. The Project 
Company will use a computerized database, which will have the following merits: (i) more robust 
decision  making  based  on  a  greater  pool  of  data,  (ii)  the  ability  to  share  information  and 
experiences with external agencies, (iii) enhance professional skills, and (iv) better information to 
encourage  policy  makers  to  prioritize  asset  management  and  maintenance.  A  number  of 
measures  will  be  introduced  with  the  help  of  the  international  consultants  to  facilitate 
implementation. They will meet three strategic objectives: (i) almost immediate: measures for 
implementation when the Project Company’s organizational structure is put in place; (ii) short 
term:  measures  for  implementation  before  expressway  completion;  and  (iii)  medium  term: 
measures for implementation within the first 2–3 years of expressway operations (Supplementary 
Appendix D). 
 
26.  Roadside  Stations. Road projects have traditionally focused on expanding transport 
capacity  to  maximize  economic  impact.  Achieving  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  by 
developing  transport  requires  innovative  approaches  that  enhance  the  multisector  and 
multipurpose dimensions of infrastructure investment. The Project’s roadside stations31 will link 
roads with community activities and encourage safe driving. Roadside stations normally provide 
parking areas and ancillary facilities such as bus terminals; gasoline stations; information centers 
about roads, road safety, and tourism; local specialty markets; restaurants; and agro-processing 
facilities. Details of facilities will be firmed up during project implementation. The Project will 
develop roadside stations along the project local roads.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Traffic Forecast 
 
43.  The traffic volume on the existing roads in the project area has been increasing at about 
10% per annum in the last 5 years. The roads are already at capacity in certain sections. If the 
new road is not constructed, traffic growth will be suppressed and transport costs will increase. 
Congested  traffic  will  slow  the  project  area’s  economic  growth.  Based  on  the  TA  findings 
(footnote 3), traffic volume on the expressway is forecast to grow from 10,615 pcu per day in 
2011 to 20,495 pcu per day in 2021, a 6.8% average annual growth rate. It will then grow more 
slowly at 5.8% per annum to reach 34,043 pcu in 2030 (Appendix 11). 
 
B.  Economic Analysis 
 
44.  To meet growing transport demand in the project area, an alternative analysis reviewed 
various options for transport modes, alignments, technical designs, timing of investments, and 
financing modalities as part of the national and provincial transport network plan. The conclusion 
was to improve road transport by constructing an expressway supported by complementary local 
road improvement. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated by comparing 
situations with and without the Project. Without the Project, the traffic volume would exceed the 
optimum capacity of the existing National Highway 108, which would become congested, thereby 
increasing travel time, vehicle operating costs (VOCs), and the number of accidents. With the 
Project, travel time would be reduced by higher speeds and shorter distance; VOCs would be 
reduced by faster and smoother travel on the expressway; and the accident rate would be 
reduced by elimination of congestion, provision of safety features, and separation of fast- and 
slow-moving traffic. If local roads are not upgraded, people in the remote parts of the project area 
will have less mobility, and the mainly poor inhabitants will not be able to participate in the 
mainstream of economic activities. The economic costs of the expressway reflect the resource 
costs for construction, O&M, and the value of agricultural production from land lost permanently. 
The economic benefits generated by the expressway include (i) savings in VOCs as a result of 
reduced road length and improved traffic conditions, (ii) time savings for road users, (iii) savings 
from avoided accidents, (iv) benefits from generated traffic, and (v) traffic diversion from rail. The 
benefits from the local roads were estimated from reduced VOCs and producer surplus (the value 
of additional production minus production costs). 
 
45.  The project EIRR is estimated at 15.2%, indicating that the Project is economically viable 
(Appendix 12). Results of sensitivity analysis confirm the robustness of the Project's economic 
viability. Changes in the key variables, such as a 10% reduction in benefits, do not significantly 
impact on economic viability. The capital cost would have to increase by 61% from the estimate 
for the EIRR to fall below the cutoff rate of 12%. The benefit level would have to decrease by 38% 
to achieve the same effect. In light of experience in the PRC road sector, variations of such 
magnitude are unlikely. The EIRR was calculated separately for the expressway (15.2%) and for 
local roads (15.9%). The economic analysis was extended to cover the distribution of project net 
benefits  by  determining  the  project  effects  for  various  beneficiaries,  including  road  users 
(passengers and freight), labor, and the government. Road users will receive the largest share of 
net benefits, accounting for 93% of the total net benefits (Appendix 12).

C.  Financial Analysis and Projections 
 
46.  The  proposed  toll  rates36 for  the  expressway  are  considered  reasonable  to  attract 
sufficient  traffic  to  meet  the  criteria  for  economic  and  financial  rate  of  return.  The  Project 
Company will undertake a toll analysis before opening the expressway, and each year for 5 years 
thereafter,  to  confirm  the  appropriate  level  of  toll,  and  it  will  submit  the  results  for  ADB’s 
concurrence. If an adjustment of the toll levels is required based on this principle, the Project 
Company  will  submit  its  toll  adjustment  plans  for  ADB’s  concurrence  before  finalizing  and

47.  Financial projections have been prepared for the Project Company in accordance with 
ADB's  Guidelines  for  the  Financial  Governance  and  Management  of  Investment  Projects 
Financed by ADB to assess the financial viability and sustainability of the Project (Appendix 13). 
The projected financial statements indicate that financial revenues will be sufficient to cover O&M 
costs,  income  taxes,  and  debt  service.  Incremental  costs  and  revenues  were  derived  by 
evaluating the financial position of the Project Company. A financial internal rate of return (FIRR) 
for the expressway, computed after taxes, is 5.4%. This compares favorably with the weighted 
average cost of capital of 3.9%. Sensitivity analysis indicates that the FIRR is robust under 
adverse conditions. Based on the financial projections and financial evaluation of the expressway 
component, the Project is considered financially viable and sustainable (Appendix 13). 
 
D.  Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy 
 
48.  The population in the project area is 938,930 (814,310 rural and 124,620 urban). Of the 
total rural population, 252,200 people (31%) are poor (annual per capita income of less than 
CNY900). Of the total urban population, 20,800 people (17%) are urban poor (less than the 
minimum standard of living), resulting in a 29% overall poverty incidence. A summary poverty 
reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 14, and a full poverty reduction and social strategy is 
in Supplementary Appendix H. 
 
49.  Most of the project area is mountainous. The productive environment in these areas is 
poor due to difficult topography, low soil fertility, and difficult climate, leading to low agricultural 
productivity. The situation is exacerbated by remoteness and poor road access, which, in turn, 
have led to weak social infrastructure, including agricultural extension, health, and education. As 
a  consequence,  off-farm  incomes  are  essential  to  reduce  poverty.  The Project  will  improve 
access to such opportunities within the project area and beyond while stimulating agricultural 
production. Road development is, however, necessary but not sufficient to facilitate growth and 
reduce poverty. Therefore, a set of complementary activities to enhance the Project’s positive 
impacts and to minimize its possible negative impacts has been agreed on with SPCD and 
included in a social development action plan (SDAP) (Supplementary Appendix I). The activities, 
which target poor villages and households, include (i) public consultation, (ii) resettlement and 
income recovery of the population affected by the expressway, (iii) prevention of the spread of 
HIV/AIDS,37 (iv) enhancement of poverty reduction impacts, and (v) tourism promotion.

E.  Environmental Assessment 
 
52.  This is an environmental category-A project. An EIA for the expressway was prepared by 
SPCD, and an environmental assessment of the local roads was prepared by the TA consultants. 
A summary EIA for the Project was prepared and circulated to the Board and made public 
through ADB's website on 24 February 2005. To ensure that all potential adverse environmental 
impacts of project design, construction, and operation are mitigated, SPCD will implement the 
environmental management plan (EMP), including a monitoring program, mitigation measures, 
institutional arrangements, and budgeting as specified in the EIA. The project expressway will 
pass through the experimental zone of Liziping Nature Reserve, based on the feasibility study, 
where multiple land uses are allowed. Potential environmental impacts on the reserve area will be 
minimized by implementing the EMP, which will be incorporated into the bidding documents and 
contracts of civil works. 
 
F.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement 
 
53.  The Project will affect five counties: Yucheng, Yingjing, Hanyuan, and Shimian in Ya’an 
municipality;  and  Mianning  in  Liangshan  Prefecture.  Based  on  the  feasibility  study,  1,466 
hectares (ha) will be acquired, 56% of which is farmland, comprising paddy (21%) and dry land 
(35%). The remaining 44% is forestland, fruit trees, housing plots, and wasteland. Approximately 
348 ha will be occupied temporarily during construction. The farmland acquisition is equivalent to 
the complete loss of farmland for 20,237 people. Along with land acquisition, about 94,800 square

54.  This is an involuntary resettlement category-A project. SPCD has conducted a social

resettlement plan, and Supplementary Appendix K for a full one). Consultations have been held

rehabilitation  strategies  have  been  prepared.  The  local  government  is  responsible  for 
implementing  the  resettlement  plan,  but  the  village  and  group  leaders  will  take  the  key

disseminated to project-affected people in February 2005. A revised resettlement plan based on 
preliminary design will be required before 31 October 2005, which provides updated impacts by 
village, rehabilitation plans for villages seriously affected by the Project, and special measures to 
support  households  that  face  hardship.  In  addition,  before  civil  works  start,  a  detailed 
measurement survey based on detailed design will be completed, providing an inventory list of 
project-affected assets. Upon completion of the survey for the project expressway and local road 
components, SPCD will submit the updated resettlement plan with any modifications to ADB 
before civil works start. 
 
G.  Risks 
 
55.  The Project was formulated to reduce potential technical, economic, financial, and social 
risks. The main technical risks are associated with the tunnel (34.5 km in total) and bridges (64.0 
km in total). To mitigate the risks, international consultants reviewed the proposed design and 
construction methods. Prequalification of contractors focuses on their financial and technical 
capability to handle complex works. During construction, monitoring and contract management 
information systems will be set up and implemented, with the assistance of the international 
consultants,  for  timely  identification  of  technical  problems  and  implementation  of  corrective 
measures. SPCD has experience, and has shown satisfactory performance, in implementing 
internationally financed projects. Economic performance in the project-influenced area would 
have to deteriorate substantially for the Project to lose its economic viability. The financial risks 
associated with construction and operation of the expressway will depend on the level and 
composition of traffic, construction costs, ability of the commercial management, and appropriate 
tolls. To mitigate the financial risks, the Project Company will build up a commercial business 
environment for expressway operations, the project expressway will receive substantial equity 
from  the  government,  and  an  appropriate  toll  structure  will  be  adopted.  For  a  project  that 
generates revenue in domestic currency, a risk is related to exchange rate changes and is partly 
accounted for in the base case calculations. An adverse exchange rate change of 30% would 
have only a small effect on the financial return. The social risks include resettlement, HIV/AIDS 
infection, and ethnic minority communities associated with the Project. Appropriate mitigation 
measures are in place in the resettlement plan, EMDP, and social action development plan.

ROAD SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Road Network 
 
1.  The road network of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) was 1.86 million kilometers 
(km) in 2004, an increase of 46,000 km from 2003. Of this, 1.44 million km were classified. 
Roads of class II and above accounted for 287,000 km, 15.3% of the total length. Road density 
has increased from 12.1 km per 100 square km (km2) in 1995 to 19.4 km per 100 km2 in 2004. 
In 2004, Sichuan’s road network accounted for 6.1% of the country’s total, with a length of 
113,043 km. Of this, 76,401 km (67.6 %) was classified: 1,758 km, expressways (1.6%); 1,496 
km, class I (1.3%); 9,633 km, class II (8.5%); and 63,514 km, of classes III and IV (56.2%). 
Unclassified roads amounted to 36,642 km (32.4%). Road density in Sichuan was 23.3 km per 
100 km2, slightly higher than the national average, but the proportion of roads under class II and 
above is significantly lower. 
 
2.  The  United  Nations  Economic  and  Social  Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific 
(UNESCAP) is promoting a transregional Asian highway network, extending 140,000 km, of 
which 26,000 km are in the PRC. Road projects funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
are helping develop this network through a total of 13 completed or planned projects comprising 
2,100 km, with a total loan amount of about $2.4 billion. 
  
B.  Vehicle Fleet and Traffic 
 
3.  In 2003, the PRC vehicle fleet totaled 24 million trucks, cars, and buses, and 72 million 
other motorized vehicles (motorcycles and agricultural vehicles). The privately owned fleet of 
motor vehicles increased more than 20 times during 1985–2003, from 0.3 million vehicles to 
12.0 million. Despite the rapid increase in total vehicles, there are only about 1.3 vehicles per 
100 people, which is lower than in other Asian countries. The PRC’s accession to the World 
Trade Organization has increased investment in the automobile industry, reduced the tariffs on 
imported vehicles, and contributed to easing motor vehicle financing. These factors, plus rapidly 
growing urban incomes, underpin the growth in road traffic. The modernization of the vehicle 
fleet will improve vehicle safety and reduce individual vehicles’ fuel consumption and their 
emissions. In 2003, the number of vehicles registered in Sichuan was 734,200 passenger 
vehicles and 392,600 freight vehicles. Vehicle ownership in Sichuan is lower than the national 
average.  Privately  owned  vehicles  totaled  670,200.  Road  passenger  traffic  in  Sichuan 
measured in terms of passenger-km of travel grew by more than 33% in 2000–2003, reaching 
47.7 billion passenger-km. Road freight traffic, in ton-km, grew by 35% during the same period. 
 
C.  Road Administration 
 
4.  The  Sichuan  Provincial  Communications  Department  (SPCD)  is  responsible  for 
regulating the road transport industry by licensing intercity bus services. Freight transport is 
essentially deregulated; however, interprovincial bus routes require Ministry of Communications 
(MOC) approval. Because of trucking reforms, private operations have increased, improving 
transport efficiency and quality of services and increasing competition. ADB is supporting this 
process through a technical assistance (TA),1 which aims to help improve the performance of 
the road transport industry by formulating policy reforms in road freight and passenger services. 
Road administration is decentralized. Road transport tariffs are allowed within a range of plus or 
minus 20% of advisory tariffs set by the local government. This flexibility, coupled with ease of

D.  Road Sector Revenue and Expenditures 
5.  Expenditures  in  highway  infrastructure  are  financed  from  dedicated  user  charges, 
government grants, domestic bank loans and bonds, and foreign loans and investments. Two 
dedicated user charges, the road maintenance fee and vehicle purchase fee, have provided 
much of the financing for the road sector. During the Ninth Five-Year Plan of 1996–2000, the 
road maintenance fee and vehicle purchase fee provided 53% and 13%, respectively, of the 
total road investments. Government grants provided 2%, mainly to construct or improve rural 
roads  in  poor  areas.  The  rest  was  financed  from  domestic  loans  and  bonds  (9%);  other 
domestic investments, including financing from local governments and state-owned enterprises 
(12%); foreign loans (8%); and foreign direct investment (3%). 
 
6.  As  part  of  a  tax  reform  to  bring  off-budget  revenue  and  expenditures  within  the 
framework of the national budget, the National People’s Congress amended the Highway Law 
on 31 October 1999, laying the foundation for legislation providing for national taxes to replace 
provincial and local fees. The vehicle purchase fee was replaced by the vehicle purchase tax 
effective January 2001, and a fuel tax is being considered to replace the road maintenance fee. 
Based on findings of an ADB-financed TA,2 the fuel tax is likely to improve financing of the road 
sector.  
 
7.  SPCD invested about CNY16.2 billion in the road sector in 2004: CNY12.9 billion for 
construction and CNY1.4 billion for maintenance. During the 10th Five-Year Plan (2001–2005), 
total investment is expected to be about CNY71 billion, with an annual average growth rate of 
5.0% during this period. SPCD plans to increase road investment to CNY78 billion during the 
11th Five-Year Plan. 
 
E.  Road Engineering, Construction, and Maintenance 
 
8.  Road  projects  are  designed  by  planning  and  design  institutes  at  the  provincial, 
prefecture, and county levels. MOC reviews the designs of expressways, high-standard roads, 
and  associated  structures.  Design  institutes  are  staffed  with  experienced,  well-qualified 
personnel. The city and county highway bureaus have their own construction units to carry out 
minor projects within their administrative districts. Drawing on the experience gained under 
ADB- and World Bank-financed projects, competitive bidding practices were mandated by the 
1999 Tendering and Bidding Law.3 Many of the largest provincial and urban construction units 
are being reorganized into financially independent companies and have been awarded contracts 
individually or as partners in joint ventures on several ADB- and World Bank-financed in-country 
or overseas projects. 
 
9.  Road maintenance is well organized by the expressway companies and the highway 
administration bureaus and is carried out mainly through labor-intensive operations but with 
increasing  amounts  of  mechanized  works.  Although  maintenance  expenditures  increased 
significantly in absolute terms in the past decade and maintenance is generally adequate, 
maintenance expenditures has not increased as a percentage of total road expenditures. In

F.  Government’s Rural Road Development Program 
 
10.  MOC has prepared the National Rural Road Development Plan, under which rural roads 
will be developed in three stages. By 2005, rural roads will make up 1.55 million km; by 2010,

region will be linked with asphalt or cement roads, and the same targets will be applied to 80% 
villages in the central region and to 90% towns in the western region. 
 
G.  Road Transport Services 
11.  A relaxation of trucking regulations in the 1980s allowed privately owned trucks to haul 
cargo for state-owned factories and cooperatives. Privately owned trucks expanded their market 
share during the 1990s at the expense of state-owned transport companies, many of which are 
now being privatized. The competition improves road transport efficiency and service quality. 
MOC is encouraging the private sector to augment the overall capacity of the road transport 
industry. More small freight operators will merge and more large state-owned companies will be 
privatized.

RURAL ROAD DEVELOPMENT AND LOCAL ROAD COMPONENT  
 
1.  The rural road forms the basic element of the national road network and provides basic 
access  to  rural  populations.  The  Government  invests  about  CNY20  billion  in  rural  road 
development annually, compared with only CNY1 billion–2 billion annually before 2003. Total 
mileage  of  newly  built  rural  road  every  year  is  about  50,000  kilometers  (km)  and  that  of 
reconstruction is about 150,000 km. In 2004, total mileage of rural road reached 1.42 million km. 
The Government built 102,000 km of rural roads in 2003, and 250,000 km in 2004, building 
about 192,000 km of paved rural roads. In 2004, along with building roads connecting to 123 
townships  and  11,200  villages,  the  Government  built  paved  roads  connecting  to  1,690 
townships and 57,500 villages. 
 
2.  The State Council approved the Rural Road Development Plan in February 2005. The 
overall objective of the plan aimed at 2020 is that the townships and villages will be accessible 
to paved roads, forming a rural road network with high service level, making travel more rapid, 
safe, and comfortable for farmers. The development goal is that by 2010, all townships in the 
People’s Republic of China will be connected to paved roads and all villages in eastern and 
central regions will be connected to paved roads by 2010. In 2010, total mileage of rural roads 
will be 3.1 million km. This is expected to increase to 3.7 million km by 2020, improving density 
and service level of rural roads. 
 
3.  The project expressway is supported by the local road component, thereby improving 
access to townships and villages in the project area. By lowering transport costs and travel 
times, the Project will foster trade, economic development, growth, and incomes in the region. In 
doing so, it will help reduce the prices of daily necessities in local markets and villages served 
by its interchanges and improve access to external markets, information, services, and income-
earning  opportunities.  These  benefits  will  be  increased  and  more  widely  distributed  by 
integrating the 678 km of local road upgrading to the project design (Tables A5.1 and A5.2). The 
importance of improving local roads is in line with the Government’s policies. According to the 
Rural Poverty Reduction Development Outline, road construction projects will be extended to 
poor areas to link their townships to national and provincial trunk roads. 
 
4.  Under the technical assistance,1 the local road component was formulated based on the 
following principles: (i) it will explicitly target the improvement of access to poor townships and 
villages and connecting them to the national and provincial road network in the project area, (ii) 
the  prime  emphasis  will  be  on providing  all-weather  access  to the  remaining  centers  and 
improving all-weather roads to poor villages, and (iii) the program should recognize the local 
priorities for road improvement. The component was prioritized by the number of the poor 
served by the road. Township and village roads were ranked separately because a township’s 
population includes the populations of villages in its administrative area. Once ranked, the top 
two thirds in each category were selected. A road survey followed the initial screening process

TRANSPORT SERVICES IN THE PROJECT AREA 
 
A.  Passenger Transport 
 
1.  The bus transport industry is regulated by the transport administration bureaus (TABs) at 
the provincial, prefecture, and county levels. All bus operators need an operating license and all 
buses have to be licensed for a specific route. The TAB may, in principle, grant licenses to more 
than one operator on the same route, Yingjing county, however, has only one licensed bus 
operator. Fares for journeys terminating at townships or larger towns are regulated by the 
provincial price bureau. Fares for township to village journeys are not regulated.  
 
2.  A  relatively  dense  network  of  bus  routes  connects  almost  all  the  townships  in  the 
province, serving all the villages on the routes. Nevertheless, many villages with poor or no road 
access still have no direct bus service. There are no cross-county routes that provide direct 
connections across township boundaries without going through township centers.  
 
3.  The  government  is  encouraging  private  involvement  in  the  transport  sector.  State 
companies are now being sold off. Regulated fares are only a little higher than financial vehicle 
operating costs per passenger for mini-buses operating on township and village roads, but that 
net margins for medium buses on good roads are attractive. Bus operators report that their 
businesses are profitable, especially the longer-distance services.   
 
4.  The TABs control the number of operators on each route in order to prevent “over-
supply,” while the number of trips per day carried out by each operator is controlled, either 
through operator associations or directly by state-owned bus terminal companies, which control 
the bus schedule and allocate slots to operators. It would appear that these restrictive operating 
practices result in low vehicle utilization and, as a consequence, unnecessarily high operating 
costs.  
 
5.  In  the  project  area,  although  the  number  of  buses  in  operation  has  substantially 
increased, this is mainly accounted for by a shift towards smaller buses.  The majority of 
licensees are individuals; the number of company licensees has fallen significantly since 1997 
and now only represents 12% of the total.  Total passenger volumes in the project area have 
increased by 60% since 1997, although passenger-kilometers have only increased by 40%.  
 
B.  Freight Transport 
 
6.  Any commercial trucking operation requires a license, which is issued by the prefecture 
TAB. Own-account trucking (for the transport of goods within the same enterprise) does not 
need  a TAB  license.  Operators  must  meet  basic  requirements  on  financial  resources  and 
maintenance capacity.  The licenses are of indefinite duration and a small fee is payable on 
initial licensing and for the annual vehicle inspections.  There is no annual license fee.  
 
7.  The Ministry of Communications publishes guidelines on freight rates but truckers are 
not obliged to follow them.  In practice, rates are negotiated between the shipper and the trucker 
and are normally much lower than the guidelines.

8.  The vast majority of truck operators are individuals. There are some large companies, 
state-owned and private, but their number has fallen substantially since 1997. Like the bus 
industry, state trucking is being privatized.  The market appears to be genuinely competitive. 
There appear to be no unreasonable restrictions on the granting of licenses, and there is 
adequate trucking capacity. 
 
9.  In the project area, freight services are diverse and made up of short-distance transport 
of bulk goods such as cement, bricks, coal, and agricultural inputs, by medium-sized trucks; 
transport of manufactured goods into the area and agricultural produce out of the area by 
medium-sized and small trucks, either owner-operated or owned by the trader; and transport of 
small quantities of produce and goods by agricultural vehicle, horse, and individuals, especially 
to and from townships. 
 
10.  Overall there has been little increase in freight carried since 1997, and haul distances 
also have remained static.  Ownership of all motorized vehicles, especially in the mountainous 
parts of the project area, is very low.  Fewer than 10% of households own agricultural vehicles.  
However, it is expected that vehicle ownership will rise as road conditions improve in the project 
area. 
 
C.  Transport Demand 
 
11.  Excluding travel within villages, the most trips by rural residents are made to the county 
towns and township centers.  Data from the social surveys show the following: 
 
(i)  The great majority of households make at least one trip per year to county towns 
and township centers. 
(ii)  The frequency of trips to township centers is much greater (47 trips per annum 
on average compared with 29 to county towns).  
(iii)  The great majority of trips to county towns are by bus whereas to township 
centers they are made on foot.  Trips by other modes are negligible.  Overall 
around 58% of trips are motorized with around 80% of these being made by bus.  
(iv)  The main trip purposes are trading and the sale of produce, business trips, 
shopping, and social. Far more trips to townships centers are for the trade and 
sale  of  produce  than  to  county  towns;  the  situation  is  reversed  for 
shopping/social trips.  
(v)  In most respects, the travel characteristics of the poor are similar to those of the 
nonpoor. This holds true for poor households and all residents of poor villages. 
There is one major, and crucial, exception: journey frequency—the poor travel 
much less than the nonpoor.   
 
12.  The major problem perceived by local residents was the poor quality of the access 
roads, which limit the availability of bus services and make travel time-consuming and difficult, 
particularly in times of heavy rains or winter snows. 
 
D.  Conclusions  
 
13.  The  bus  system  is  closely  regulated  down  to  township  level  but  flexible  on  route 
planning. The rate of growth of routes is increasing as National Road 108 and township roads 
are improved. This can be taken as a strong indication that, where road access is possible and 
where demand is sufficient to ensure profitability, services will be provided.

14.  Where bus services are not available or are inappropriate, transport is generally by foot 
or horse in the mountainous areas, and by foot, bicycle, or motorcycle in valley areas. Trishaws 
operate in urban areas and adjacent villages. The majority of households in rural areas make 
trips, although they make substantially fewer trips. There is, however, no evidence that they do 
not avail themselves of public transport services when they need them.  
 
15.  Although there is no compelling evidence that fares are excessive compared with costs, 
the TABs could do more to promote competition between bus operators. With completion of 
more expressway links, it will become possible to license new routes. This would help ensure 
that any savings in vehicle operating costs (VOCs) arising from road improvements are passed 
on to passengers and will increase operational efficiency and promote service quality. The cost 
reductions brought about by road improvements make it more likely that new or more frequent 
services will be introduced by a flexible bus transport sector.   
 
16.  As for the freight transport, the characteristics of the transport services industry in the 
project area do not impede the commercialization of agriculture, as it is sufficiently flexible and 
competitive to provide whatever scale and kind of services that may be required. There appear 
to be no restraints on the supply of freight transport services. Vehicles are relatively cheap and 
credit to purchase them readily available. Rates are set competitively and supply responds 
effectively to changes in demand. Competition between the transport operators should ensure 
that any savings in vehicle operating costs, which might arise from road improvements, would 
be passed on to the users. 
 
17.  Fruit, the main cash crop, is mostly sold direct to traders at the farmgate. As there are 
significant numbers of traders, competition between them should ensure that some of the VOC 
savings are passed on to the farmers in higher prices. Improved roads will also enable access 
by  smaller,  cheaper  farm  vehicles,  the  purchase  of  which  will,  in  some  instances,  enable 
farmers to market more of their produce directly.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
1.  The project expressway traverses central Sichuan Province. Local roads are connected 
to the expressway through the road network system. The economic analysis covers the 26 
years of construction and operation. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of the Project 
was estimated by comparing the situation with and without the Project. Without the Project, 
traffic will use the existing road network, which will be congested and expensive to maintain due 
to the rapidly increasing volume of traffic. Some travel may not take place because of the 
congestion and the resulting increasing travel times and vehicle operating costs (VOCs). With 
the Project, congestion on the existing roads will be reduced, and traffic on the expressway and 
the existing roads will benefit from faster, cheaper, and safer travel. Additional trips will be 
generated as the economy responds to lower transport costs and better service. 
 
2.  Alternative Analysis. As part of economic analysis, possible alternative interventions 
were considered to meet the growing transport demand in the project area as part of the 
national and provincial transport network plan. Alternative analysis reviewed various options in 
terms of transport modes, alignments, technical designs, timing of investments, and financing 
modalities. While enhancing the existing railway capacity may be an option to partly meet the 
increasing demand, it will not completely satisfy the various kinds of traffic, particularly high-
value general cargo that requires a more flexible and responsive mode to meet the needs of a 
market  economy.  Six  alternative  alignments  were  reviewed  based  on  geologic  and 
topographical conditions, terrain considerations, consultations with community representatives, 
cost estimates, relative impacts on environment and resettlement, and integration with the 
national and local transport network. The expressway technical design was proposed after 
consideration of the national highway network, consistency in the standards of contiguous 
sections  at  each  end  of  the  project  expressway,  and  forecast  traffic.  Alternative  financing 
modalities  were  considered,  including  private  sector  investment.  However,  private  sector 
investment was not found attractive due to risks associated with construction and low estimated 
rates of return. Hence, public financing was considered appropriate. 
 
3.  General  Parameters.  Economic  evaluation  was  undertaken  using  constant  2005 
economic prices. The prices are expressed in yuan using the domestic price numeraire, with a 
shadow exchange rate factor of 1.013 for foreign exchange effects. A shadow price was used to 
place an economic value on the wages paid to unskilled labor, while skilled labor was not 
shadow priced since there is no surplus of skilled workers. A shadow wage rate factor of 0.67 
was used to convert the financial wage rate to an economic opportunity cost of labor. 
 
4.  Costs. The capital costs and physical contingencies for the Project are revalued at 
economic  prices  by  separating  the  cost  items  into  tradable  materials  and  equipment, 
nontradable materials, labor, and land. The land and resettlement costs were based on their 
opportunity costs, i.e., agricultural output forgone and re-siting of displaced activities. 
 
5.  Benefits. The economic benefits include (i) savings in VOCs resulting from the reduced 
travel distance and improved road conditions, (ii) savings in the value of passenger time and of 
freight tied up in transit, (iii) savings resulting from fewer accidents, (iv) benefits to generated 
traffic, and (v) savings in capital and operation and maintenance (O&M) costs for National 
Highway (NH) 108. A reduction in VOCs is the main source of economic benefits for the Project. 
Traffic diverting to the expressway would travel at high, more economical speeds on a smoother 
road,  with  better  vertical  and  horizontal  alignment,  less  congestion,  and  a  shorter  journey 
distance. Traffic remaining on the alternative NH108 route would also benefit from a reduction in 
traffic volume and congestion. All these changes affect vehicle speeds and VOCs, which were

Appendix 12  47
estimated for all vehicle types likely to use the corridor. Savings in travel time will be seen both 
on the project expressway and the existing roads. Work-related travel time was evaluated for 
private vehicles and buses. The economic cost of accidents was estimated on direct property 
damage and foregone income. 
 
6.  Six hundred seventy-eight km of local roads will be improved concurrently with the 
expressway component. The costs of this component include capital costs and O&M costs. The 
principal benefits of the local road improvements were identified as reduced VOCs and the 
producer surplus (the value of additional production minus production costs). Transport cost 
savings will accrue to normal traffic on the improved roads. The local roads recommended for 
upgrading  were  chosen  based  on  poverty  incidence,  the  effect  on  overall  road  network 
efficiency, economic development potential, and population density. 
 
7.  Result and Conclusion. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the Project, 
including the expressway and local road components, is 15.2% (Table A12.1). The EIRR for the 
expressway component alone is 15.2%, and for the local road component, 15.9%. VOC savings 
are  the  major  economic  benefit  (78%),  followed  by  travel  time  savings  (13%),  local  road 
component (3%), and accident cost savings (3%). 
 
8.  The results of the sensitivity analysis confirm the robustness of the Project’s economic 
viability: changes in the key  variables—construction costs, benefits, traffic growth, residual 
value, and 1-year delay in completion—do not significantly affect the economic viability (Table

the cutoff rate of 12%. Considering the experience of ADB in the PRC, such an increase in 
capital cost is unlikely. ADB-financed road projects in the PRC have not encountered major cost 
overruns, and the contract prices tend to be lower than estimated because the contracting 
process is becoming increasingly competitive. The benefit level would have to decrease more 
than 38% to make the Project economically nonviable. A risk analysis was carried out to 
determine the degree of uncertainty on the Project. Each uncertainty factor (such as capital 
cost, traffic growth, and VOC value) was varied at random within the limits. The results showed 
that an EIRR exceeding 12% will be achieved with a 95% probability. The economic analysis of 
the Project was extended to analyze distribution of project net benefits by determining the 
project effects for various beneficiaries, including road users (passenger and freight), labor, and 
government. It was found that road users will receive the largest share of net benefit, accounting

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT PLAN 
1.  The proposed Project will finance the construction of an expressway between Ya’an and 
Lugu, with a length of 244 kilometers (km), and a local road component with a total length of 
678 km county to township and township to village roads. The resettlement plan1 covers both 
components  based  on  the  feasibility  study.  The  proposed  Yalu  expressway  (including 
connecting  roads)  will  affect  29  townships  and  93  administrative  villages  in  five  counties: 
Yucheng, Yingjing, Hanyuan, and Shimian in Ya’an municipality; and Mianning in Liangshan 
Prefecture. The local road program involves upgrading the existing county to township and 
township to village roads, so it is not expected to involve a significant amount of land acquisition 
and resettlement. The resettlement plan will be revised after completion of the preliminary 
design, including village rehabilitation plans, and submitted to the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) for approval prior to commencement of land acquisition. 
2.  For the expressway, 1,466 hectares (ha) will be permanently acquired, of which 21% is 
paddy, 35% dryland, 15% orchard, 15% forestland, 1% housing plots, and 13% wasteland. 
Another  347.6  ha  will  be  occupied  temporarily  during  construction.  Based  on  per  capita 
farmland in affected villages, farmland acquisition will be equivalent to 20,237 people (5,711 
households) losing all their farmland. It is expected that the average loss of farmland per 
household will be 25%; 94,800 square meters (m2) of houses will be demolished, requiring 
relocation of 790 households (2,634 people). About 70% of houses are made of brick and wood, 
and earth and wood, and 30% are brick and concrete. Most of these households will be moved 
a  short  distance  within  their  original  village.  All  land,  housing,  and  other  assets  will  be 
compensated at replacement value.  
3.  For people unavoidably affected, the resettlement objective is to achieve equal or better 
income  and  living  standards  in  line  with  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  Land 
Administration  Law  (1998)  and  the  ADB’s  policy  on  involuntary  resettlement.  The  Sichuan 
Provincial  Communications  Department  (SPCD)  will  ensure  that  any  people  losing  land, 
housing, other assets, or income sources will be assisted to fully restore their income and living 
standards. A comprehensive compensation rate (for land compensation, resettlement subsidy, 
and cost of young crops) has been estimated at CNY480,000 per ha for irrigated farmland, and 
CNY300,000 per ha for dry land. Those losing land temporarily during construction will receive a 
payment equivalent to production value foregone for the period of loss, which is expected to be 
2 years.  The land used temporarily will also be restored by the contractor to the original 
condition. For structures to be demolished, replacement value will be provided to the affected 
households based on compensation rates adopted in affected city and prefecture, which range 
from CNY350 to CNY450/m2 for brick and concrete structures, CNY280 to CNY340/m2 for brick-
wood  structure,  and  CNY220  to  CNY260/m2  for  earth  and  wood  structures.  Those  losing 
housing will be compensated for their housing plot, equivalent to the rate for irrigated farmland, 
so they can acquire new housing sites close to a road and with electricity and water in their 
village  group  or  administrative  village.  Housing  compensation  will  not  be  reduced  for 
depreciation, and people will be allowed to salvage materials from their old houses. Efforts to 
minimize resettlement effects have been made after consultations with local officials during the 
setting of the alignment for the feasibility study to avoid towns, villages, and high-yield paddy 
and fruit gardens.
